9.1  In accordance with items 9.3, 9.4, and 10.3, this Contract shall come into
force on the Effective Date, remain effective throughout the Initial Term,
and be prolonged, or further extended automatically for a period of 12
months, each such extension commencing at the end of the last day of the
Initial Term or the relevant anniversary thereof, unless either Party
serves written notice of termination on the other Party at least 65 days
prior to the end of the Initial Term, or any subsequent extension.
perturbation.changed_text:
9.1  In accordance with items 9.3, 9.4, and 10.3, this Contract shall come into
force on the Effective Date, remain effective throughout the Initial Term,
and be prolonged, or further extended automatically for a period of 12
months, each such extension commencing at the end of the last day of the
Initial Term or the relevant anniversary thereof, unless either Party
serves written notice of termination on the other Party at least 15 days
prior to the end of the Initial Term, or any subsequent extension.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for contract termination to 15 days may violate laws in some jurisdictions that mandate longer notice periods to protect the parties involved from abrupt termination without sufficient time to prepare.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially contradicts contract law principles requiring reasonable notice for termination, varying by jurisdiction but often exceeding 15 days.

this Contract, and keeps non-performing it, then the Principal may upon

perturbation.changed_text:
9.3  If the Company fails to perform within 10 days upon notice from the
Principal on nonperformance by the Company of any of its obligations under
this Contract, and keeps non-performing it, then the Principal may upon

perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period to 10 days may be considered unreasonably short, particularly for complex contractual obligations, potentially conflicting with legal principles of fairness and adequate opportunity to remedy a breach.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates contract law principles requiring a reasonable opportunity to cure a breach, varying by jurisdiction and specific contractual context.
